DOC.HEAD: 26,000 Indonesians To Be Sent Home to Obtain Proper Documents
DOC.TEXT: Malaysian authorities today began ferrying 26,000 illegal immigrants home to obtain proper documents so they can return here to work. Director General of Immigration Syed Alwi Syed Nordin was at Malacca port, 90 miles southwest of Kuala Lumpur, to send off the first batch of 76 Indonesians. It will take the government about a year to send back all 26,000 Indonesian illegal immigrants registered with his department, the national news agency Bernama quoted him as telling reporters there. An average of 500 will be sent back weekly across the Malacca Straits, he added. Most will be sent to Dumai, on Indonesia's Sumatra Island, where it would take two days for them to obtain valid Indonesian travel documents, he said. The first batch was expected back Sunday in Malacca. On their return, they were to be issued Malaysian visas and three-year work permits, which could be renewed if necessary. Syed said that to keep track of the Indonesian workers in Malaysia, the government had urged them to register with the authorities so that they could be issued legal documents. The Indonesian government had been consulted and agreed to this, he added. The 26,000 who have registered mostly worked on palm oil, rubber and other plantations.
